title: नीतिशतकम् 1
meaning: Salutations to that peaceful Light, which is the embodiment of pure, infinite consciousness, unconditioned by direction, time, etc., and which can be known only through self-realization.

title: नीतिशतकम् 2
full: बोद्धारो मत्सर-ग्रस्ताः प्रभवः स्मय-दूषिताः । अबोधोपहताः चान्ये जीर्णमङ्गे सुभाषितम् ॥
अर्थः: विद्वांसः द्वेषेण आवृताः । समर्थाः राजानः अहङ्कारेण मलिनाः । इतरे साधारणाः सुभाषितानि अवगन्तुम् असमर्थाः । एवं सति सुभाषितं वक्तुः मुखे एव जीर्णं भवति ।व्यर्थः भवति इति भावः ।
meaning: The learned are consumed by envy, the powerful are corrupted by pride, and others are afflicted with ignorance. Thus, wise sayings perish within oneself, finding no worthy recipient.

title: नीतिशतकम् 3
full: अज्ञः सुखमाराध्यः सुखतरमाराध्यते विशेषज्ञः । ज्ञान-लव-दुर्विदग्धं ब्रह्मापि नरं न रञ्जयति ॥
meaning: An ignorant person is easy to please, and an expert is even easier to please. However, even the creator Brahma cannot satisfy a person who is puffed up with a mere particle of knowledge.

title: नीतिशतकम् 4
full: प्रसह्य मणिमुद्धरेन्मकर-वक्त्र-दंष्ट्रान्तरात्समुद्रमपि सन्तरेत्प्रचलदूर्मि-मालाकुलम् । भुजङ्गमपि कोपितं शिरसि पुष्पवद्धारयेत्न तु प्रतिनिविष्ट-मूर्ख-जन-चित्तमाराधयेत् ॥
meaning: One might forcibly extract a gem from between a crocodile's teeth, cross an ocean agitated by rows of surging waves, and even wear an enraged serpent on one's head like a flower. But one can never please the mind of a stubborn fool.
